commit_message:
Add documentation of algorithm for version discovery

It turns out this has a lot of edge cases and needs to be clearly
defined.

Co-Authored-By: Samuel de Medeiros Queiroz <samueldmq@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Idd0d7d40ac393b80c262f72f401cc711e97b6d10
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/65/458565/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================= Version Discovery ================= Version discovery in OpenStack can be rather complex, with a dizzying array of combinations of what a user desires, what the cloud offers, and quirks of history. The following is a description of how shade deals with version discovery in OpenStack. For the most part, a user should never need to think about this, but in some cases it can be useful to know what it's doing and how to affect it. Configuration ============= For any given service, there are two optional values a user can provide, ``{service}_api_version`` and ``{service}_endpoint_override`` - where service is the ``service_type`` value, such as ``compute``, ``image`` or ``file-storage``. It is expected that shade will figure out and do the right thing in the absence of either value and that they should only be needed in exceptional cases. Discovery Algorithm =================== The approach for determining the endpoint is based on whether a version is provided and on whether the service's endpoint in the keystone catalog is versioned or unversioned. The algorithm is as follows: #. If the user has provided ``{service}_endpoint_override`` use it unconditionally. #. Retrieve the discovery document at the URL provided in the catalog. Determine if it is a single or multiple version document (see :ref:`single-or-multiple`) and normalize it (see :ref:`normalize-document`) #. If there is no document at the URL provided in the catalog, find a working document. (see :ref:`find-document`) #. If it is not possible to find a working discovery URL, use the endpoint from the catalog and infer the API version. (see :ref:`inferring-version`) #. If ``{service}_api_version`` is not provided and the discovery document is a multiple version document, pick the endpoint with the latest version that shade knows how to deal with. #. If ``{service}_api_version`` is not provided and the discovery document is a single version document, use the endpoint it contains. #. If ``{service}_api_version`` is provided and the discovery document is a multiple version document, and there is a match in the document for the version requested, use that endpoint. #. If ``{service}_api_version`` is provided and the discovery document is a multiple version document, and there is not an endpoint in the document for the version requested, find the endpoint in the document that matches the endpoint from the catalog and use it, so that version will be known. (see :ref:`matching-endpoints`) If no endpoint matches, use the catalog endpoint and infer the api version (see :ref:`inferring-version`) #. If ``{service}_api_version`` is provided and the discovery document is a single version document and the version in the document matches the provided version, use it. #. If ``{service}_api_version`` is provided and the discovery document is a single version document and the version in the document does not match the provided version, find a better document and apply the discovery algorithm again. (see :ref:`find-document`) #. When an endpoint has been found, expand it and return it for use. (see :ref:`expanding-endpoints`) .. _find-document: Find a Document =============== In some cases, the discovery URL will either not return a document, or will not return the document we want, so we need to look for a new one. The algorithm for that is as follows: #. If the current discovery endpoint ends with a version string of the form "v[0-9]+.*", pop that element from the end of the endpoint and return to discovery with this new endpoint. #. Get the curently scoped ``project_id`` from the token, if one exists. #. If the current discovery endpoint ends with the ``project_id``, pop the ``project_id`` from the end of the endpoint but make a note of having done so for later. Return to discovery with this new endpoint. #. If no new endpoint can be found, then return to discovery reporting no working discovery document. .. _inferring-version: Inferring Version ================= In most cases the version of the endpoint should be retreivable from the version discovery document, and in those cases it should be considered the version of the service at the endpoint. There are two cases where a version must be inferred with only the endpoint to go on: * If the user has provided ``{service}_endpoint_override`` with no corresponding ``{service}_api_version``. * If an endpoint could not be found in a discovery document and the endpoint in the catalog is used. The algorithm for inferring the version is as follows: #. If the endpoint contains a path element anywhere that is of the form, "^v[0-9]+\.?[0-9]*$", strip the v and use the rest as the version. #. If the endpoint contains no version elements and the service is known to have more than one existing API version, assume the earliest known version. Issue a warning to the user that it was not possible to reliably infer a version. .. _matching-endpoints: Matching Endpoints ================== If a multiple version document exists but the discovery algorithm has chosen to fall back to the endpoint provided by the catalog, a URL matching the catalog URL should be found so that the version can be extracted. #. Get the curently scoped ``project_id`` from the token, if one exists. #. If the current catalog endpoint ends with the ``project_id``, save the ``project_id`` for later. #. Sort the endpoints in the discovery document by version in descending order. Then, for each endpoint in that list, expand the endpoint (see :ref:`expanding-endpoints`) and compare to the catalog endpoint. The first endpoint that matches is the winner. .. _expanding-endpoints: Expanding Endpoints =================== Endpoints in discovery documents can be relative and can also be erroneous in known ways. Before using endpoints from discovery documents, they must be expanded. The algorithm is as follows: #. If the endpoint from the discovery document is relative, join it with the endpoint that the discovery document was fetched from. ``six.moves.urllib.parse.urljoin`` does the right thing and can be used unconditionally. #. Replace the ``scheme`` of the endpoint from the discovery document with the ``scheme`` from the endpoint it was fetched from. This is because some services have buggy discovery documents that return incorrect schemes. For example: .. code-block:: python def replace_scheme(endpoint, discovery_url): parsed_endpoint = urllib.parse.urlparse(endpoint) parsed_discovery_url = urllib.parse.urlparse(discovery_url) return urllib.parse.ParseResult( parsed_discovery_url.scheme, parsed_endpoint.netloc, parsed_endpoint.path, parsed_endpoint.params, parsed_endpoint.query, parsed_endpoint.fragment).geturl() #. If a ``project_id`` has previously been saved, either from finding the document or as part of matching endpoints, append it to the end of the endpoint. .. _single-or-multiple: Single or Multiple Version Documents ==================================== There are three forms of version discovery documents in the wild, two that contain lists of endpoint versions and one that is for a single version. In order to apply the discovery algorithm, the type of document must be detected. #. If the document has a top level key of ``versions``, it is a multiple version document. #. If the document has a top level key of ``version``, it is a single version document. #. If the document has neither but is a single dict that contains a key of ``id``, it is a single version document. .. _normalize-document: Normalizing Documents ===================== There exist several forms of discovery documents in the wild, and there exists an `API WG document`_ about the desired state of the documents. In order to apply the other algorithms sanely, the fetched documents should be normalized to align with the `API WG document`_. #. If the document has a key named ``versions`` which contains a dict with a key named ``values``, move the list contained in values to be directly under ``versions``. That list is then the list of Version objects. #. If the document has a key named ``version``, that is the Version object. For each Version object: #. Convert the value in the ``status`` field to upper case. #. If ``status`` is ``STABLE``, change it to ``CURRENT``. (handles keystone) #. If there is a ``version`` field and not a ``min_version`` field, make a ``min_version`` field with the value from the ``version`` field. (handles nova microversions) #. Keys other than ``id``, ``min_version``, ``max_version``, ``status`` and ``links`` can be ignored or removed. #. The ``links`` key should contain a list, and that list should contain one dict with ``rel`` equal to ``self``. Any other entries can be discarded. .. _API WG document: https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/microversion_specification.html#version-discovery

    Initial implementation

    Changes in the mechanism driver:

        * Automatically create a port with device_owner=network:dhcp to
          serve metadata and eventually DHCP.
        * Auto-allocate an IP for the metadata port on subnet creation.
        * Push static route for 169.254.169.254 in DHCP options.

    Agent:

        * Implementation of [0]

    Devstack plugin:

        * Starts networking-ovn-agent with the proper config files.
        * Disables config drive in nova.conf.
        * Disables TEMPEST_RUN_VALIDATION

    TODO:

          force_config_drive = False
        * [neutron] section:
          service_metadata_proxy = True

    This patch depends on [1] (already merged into OVS master) and [2].

commit_message:
[WIP] Metadata agent support in networking-ovn

    Initial implementation

    Changes in the mechanism driver:

        * Automatically create a port with device_owner=network:dhcp to
          serve metadata and eventually DHCP.
        * Auto-allocate an IP for the metadata port on subnet creation.
        * Push static route for 169.254.169.254 in DHCP options.

    Agent:

        * Implementation of [0]

    Devstack plugin:

        * Starts networking-ovn-agent with the proper config files.
        * Disables config drive in nova.conf.
        * Disables TEMPEST_RUN_VALIDATION

    TODO:

        * Write tests.
        * Wait until we're serving metadata for a certain datapath before
          sending the vif plugged event to Nova.

    In order to test this patch out we need to make this changes to
    nova.conf:

        * [DEFAULT] section:
          force_config_drive = False
        * [neutron] section:
          service_metadata_proxy = True

    This patch depends on [1] (already merged into OVS master) and [2].

    [0]
    https://docs.openstack.org/developer/networking-ovn/design/metadata_api.html
    [1] https://patchwork.ozlabs.org/patch/767369/
    [2] https://patchwork.ozlabs.org/patch/771297/

    Change-Id: Ife2fd18f2f88050429e70c7e557fa41d2d54b034

Change-Id: I2afa722d30d87623a8c69335a2691075481ca30d

commit_message:
Switch NFS driver to use DLM locks

To be able to use NFS driver with c-vol in A/A deployment, it needs to
use DLM as locking mechanism. Without that we can expect errors for
example when snapshots are managed by multiple nodes concurrently.

NfsDriver class is inherited by multiple vendor drivers. Affected
drivers are listed below:

* NetAppCmodeNfsDriver
* NetApp7modeNfsDriver
* CohoDriver
* NexentaNfsDriver
* NexentaNfsDriver (ns5)
* TintriNfsDriver
* ZFSSANFSDriver
* GPFSNFSDriver
* HNASNFSDriver

Closes-Bug: 1660584

Change-Id: Iafdb29546bfc8d57aee4f8b3f85ab51f49432814

commit_message:
Add description for function do_list_extensions in cinderclient

Now the current cinderclient version default use v3 interface.
And the do_list_extensions of V3 inherited V2. The do_list_extensions
of V2 does not have __doc__.For the cli-reference, there is a specific
docs tool used  to auto-generate the cli-reference files.The docs tool
find the function __doc__ that starts with 'do_',as The
do_list_extensions's __doc__ is none,so the subcommand 'list-extensions'
no desc.

python-cinderclient/cinderclient/shell.py
---------------------------------
def _find_actions(self, subparsers, actions_module, version,
                      do_help, input_args):
        for attr in (a for a in dir(actions_module) if
a.startswith('do_')):
            # I prefer to be hyphen-separated instead of underscores.
            command = attr[3:].replace('_', '-')
            callback = getattr(actions_module, attr)
            desc = callback.__doc__ or ''
            .......

The OpenStack contributor guide has instructions. The guide has a
chapter on how to use the duto-generate docs tools
- https://docs.openstack.org/contributor-guide/doc-tools.html
Specifically, the chapter on the command line reference explains
how the tool works -
https://docs.openstack.org/contributor-guide/doc-tools/cli-reference.html

Change-Id: I5484d1e25b4ec11182b27c80fc43e816b1a12736
Closes-Bug: #1674934

commit_message:
Use plain routes list for block_device_mapping instead of stevedore

This patch adds block_device_mapping related routes by a plain list, instead
of using stevedore. After all the Nova API endpoints moves to the
plain routes list, the usage of stevedore for API loading
will be removed from Nova.

Partial-implement-blueprint api-no-more-extensions-pike

Change-Id: I3d1774943708db3c285ca6597898393349970c7b

commit_message:
Rename auth_url -> auth_uri in configure_auth_token_middleware

Actually this parameter is called "auth_uri" not "auth_url"[1],
so should be renamed in the configuration code.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/keystonemiddleware/blob/master/keystonemiddleware/auth_token/_opts.py#L31
Closes-bug: #1698006

Change-Id: I9b30ebd4378a150a6bf682d8451e4d920e4af4eb

commit_message:
RESTify create_server

In order to create passing tags to the nics parameter of create_server,
we need to support microversions. In order to support microversions, we
need to be using REST. Yolanda needs to pass tags to the nics parameter,
so let's go ahead and transition create_server since we want to anyway.

Tests are modified to remove an extra GET call that novaclient makes
that we don't actually need.

A follow up to this will add microversion discovery, and then will add
support for 'tags' being in the nics list.

Change-Id: I04c3b08d80cf496dabec8ce7000ca5fb679fe3b9

commit_message:
VMAX driver - Rollback error on Live Migration

This patch fixes an issue where errorMessage is not getting reassigned
from None in the method ._get_port_group_name_from_mv., having the knock
on effect where errors are not being picked up in subsequent calls or
conditional checks.

Change-Id: I74a85aaa912a7f4c22abbf48f0a5d1bd4538c098
Closes-Bug: #1686174
(cherry picked from commit b44f55c5163579e720b4f19a09be2e0a859e43d7)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/80/469080/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Don't fetch extra_specs in functional tests

We don't need to get these with every list_flavors and they make the
logs harder to read.

Change-Id: I642f6e0f05b13b67e95ed2cefdf7230c2cda5e5c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/83/473583/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Convert create_server mocks to request_mock

Next patch will convert create_server. Note: this found a few bugs in
the tests.

Change-Id: Ia1c9d3a02e52b63756f61dbff77b90dc35e45d24

subject: DVR: Fix DVR Router snat ports and gateway ports host binding issue
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-01 23:31:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/e95a5e69a62ef0b93c46bc2beebb5ad534f889d3', 'message': "DVR: Fix DVR Router ports and gateway ports host binding issue

DVR Router ports and gateway ports are not bound to any host
and so we don't see the snat namespace getting created.

The issue is the _build_routers_list in l3_dvr_db.py is not called due
to the inheritance order.

Change-Id: I56f9de31524aeef262cf2a78be3abf8487c21a12
Closes-Bug: # 1695101
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-06-02 22:15:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/44f9bd1ad958ac173e95725b2dd0548644ab97bb', 'message': "DVR: Fix DVR Router snat ports and gateway ports host binding issue

DVR snat ports and gateway ports are not bound to any host
and so we don't see the snat namespace getting created.

The issue is the _build_routers_list in l3_dvr_db.py is not called due
to the inheritance order.

Change-Id: I56f9de31524aeef262cf2a78be3abf8487c21a12
Closes-Bug: #1695101
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-06-07 22:06:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/b0887b741fc57ffad52a7e35a302e730698418cb', 'message': "DVR: Fix DVR Router snat ports and gateway ports host binding issue

DVR snat ports and gateway ports are not bound to any host
and so we don't see the snat namespace getting created.

The issue is the _build_routers_list in l3_dvr_db.py is not called due
to the inheritance order.

commit_message:
DVR: Fix DVR Router snat ports and gateway ports host binding issue

DVR snat ports and gateway ports are not bound to any host
and so we don't see the snat namespace getting created.

The issue is the _build_routers_list in l3_dvr_db.py is not called due
to the inheritance order.

Change-Id: I56f9de31524aeef262cf2a78be3abf8487c21a12
Closes-Bug: #1695101

commit_message:
add instruction to set auth_mode

we need auth_mode set in gnocchi3.1+ or else it won't use keystone

Change-Id: I3fb8173dd4637514c06f7fec6cd86aa42038120f
(cherry picked from commit b8960479ac7cc0190f308a99f0ab5a7e9f550e31)

commit_message:
Fix whitespace linter trap

When the linter fails due to trailing whitespaces, the trapped
dump_logs.sh execution will attempt to collect logs using kubectl,
which is not installed, causing further errors in the log.
This patch set prevents the log gathering if kubectl does not
exists.

Change-Id: I83c13caec2ece7cc8ec9bfd838ae7d4af9dcbed3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm refs/changes/49/474049/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # if the linter fails with errno = 2, just bail since there # is no environment to capture. if [[ $1 == 2 ]] ; then exit $1 fi

commit_message:
Ignore some files during running tox

When we run "tox" command, there are two
redundancy files named AUTHORS and ChangeLog.
They should be ignored.

Change-Id: Ia49bbe32f32054365f6380709edf55083693b019

commit_message:
Fix the CLI symbol in the quickstart doc

The CLI propmpt symbol in the updated doc was changed to #, which
implies root. Lets not encourage people to run a bunch of things as
root. This patch reverts it to $

Change-Id: Iac7343e676cc58b79e7328cdbad1652f98da0ecf
Implements: blueprint pike-docs-overhaul

commit_message:
Install specific version of Erlang from ESL

The RabbitMQ community and project recommend erlang 19.3.x for the best,
most stable, results. This change downloads the recommended version of
erlang [ https://www.rabbitmq.com/which-erlang.html ] from ESL and moves
the erlang packages for distros into a specific list installed only when
the ``rabbitmq_install_method`` variable is not set to "file".

Change-Id: Ief57b1fdcb791f0f8ed20c1cbb54ea19d4373f81
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Dynamically include upgrade_check task files

Dynamically include the correct galera_upgrade_check task file based on
the ansible_pkg_mgr variable.

Change-Id: Icf7a2556fc303f8920a85873a6f44d4548b7f459
(cherry picked from commit bc963815ca252f55fed36f018d6c0eaffb49f01c)

commit_message:
Skip pagination test for now

The pagination test, although awesome, is killing the cinder in the gate
and we're seeing an unworkable increase in timeouts.

Skip the test for now allowing us to work on fixing the test without
killing everything else.

Change-Id: If83abbad9398cb97ca7fdc1d3f6d2d5473343664

commit_message:
Role Specific parameters for neutron-sriov-agent service

Merge the role specific parmaeter with the default parameter with the
higher precendece given to role specific parameters. Use the merged
settings for the hiera config settings.

Change-Id: I7d12ea7a26ba5c22d7961c59fb63663fc2a6b4cd
Signed-off-by: Sanjay Upadhyay <supadhya@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/64/469464/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: heat_template_version: pike description: > OpenStack Neutron SR-IOV nic agent configured with Puppet parameters: ServiceNetMap: default: {} description: > Mapping of service_name -> network name. Typically set via parameter_defaults in the resource registry. This mapping overrides those in ServiceNetMapDefaults. type: json DefaultPasswords: default: {} type: json RoleName: default: '' description: Role name on which the service is applied type: string RoleParameters: default: {} description: Parameters specific to the role type: json EndpointMap: default: {} description: Mapping of service endpoint -> protocol. Typically set via parameter_defaults in the resource registry. type: json NeutronPhysicalDevMappings: description: > List of <physical_network>:<physical device> All physical networks listed in network_vlan_ranges on the server should have mappings to appropriate interfaces on each agent. Example "tenant0:ens2f0,tenant1:ens2f1" type: comma_delimited_list default: "" NeutronExcludeDevices: description: > List of <network_device>:<excluded_devices> mapping network_device to the agent's node-specific list of virtual functions that should not be used for virtual networking. excluded_devices is a semicolon separated list of virtual functions to exclude from network_device. The network_device in the mapping should appear in the physical_device_mappings list. type: comma_delimited_list default: "" NeutronSriovNumVFs: description: > Provide the list of VFs to be reserved for each SR-IOV interface. Format "<interface_name1>:<numvfs1>,<interface_name2>:<numvfs2>" Example "eth1:4096,eth2:128" type: comma_delimited_list default: "" resources: NeutronBase: type: ./neutron-base.yaml properties: ServiceNetMap: {get_param: ServiceNetMap} DefaultPasswords: {get_param: DefaultPasswords} EndpointMap: {get_param: EndpointMap} RoleName: {get_param: RoleName} RoleParameters: {get_param: RoleParameters} # Merging role-specific parameters (RoleParameters) with the default parameters. # RoleParameters will have the precedence over the default parameters. RoleParameterValue: type: OS::Heat::Value properties: type: json value: map_replace: - map_replace: - neutron::agents::ml2::sriov::physical_device_mappings: NeutronPhysicalDevMappings neutron::agents::ml2::sriov::exclude_devices: NeutronExcludeDevices tripleo::host::sriov::number_of_vfs: NeutronSriovNumVFs - values: {get_param: [RoleParameters]} - values: NeutronPhysicalDevMappings: {get_param: NeutronPhysicalDevMappings} NeutronExcludeDevices: {get_param: NeutronExcludeDevices} NeutronSriovNumVFs: {get_param: NeutronSriovNumVFs} outputs: role_data: description: Role data for the Neutron SR-IOV nic agent service. value: service_name: neutron_sriov_agent config_settings: map_merge: - map_replace: - get_attr: [NeutronBase, role_data, config_settings] - get_attr: [RoleParametersValue, value] # step_config: | # include ::tripleo::profile::base::neutron::sriov

subject: Sample environment generator
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-04 18:22:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/cac1e7e5e822b03a6fad0e36bac41ac678e711be', 'message': "WIP: Sample environment generator

This is a tool to automate the generation of our sample environment
files.  It takes a yaml file as input, and based on the environments
defined in that file generates a number of sample environment files
from the parameters in the Heat templates.

A basic rundown of the settings in the input file:
- name: the output file will be this name + .yaml
- description: A description of the environment.  Will be included
  as a comment at the top of the sample file.
- files: The Heat templates containing the parameter definitions
  for the environment.
- parameters: This can be either a list of parameters related to
  the environment, which is necessary for templates like
  overcloud.yaml, or the string 'all', which indicates that all
  parameters from $files should be included.
- immutable: Can be used to specify that certain parameters must
  not be changed.  Examples would be the EnableSomething params
  in the templates.  If you're writing a sample config for Something
  then EnableSomething: True would be an immutable param.
- private: Used to specify that some parameters are only for
  internal communication between the templates and should not be
  included in the sample file (this would only be useful for the
  'all' parameters setting).
- sample_values: Sometimes it is useful to include a sample value
  for a parameter that is not the parameter's actual default.
  An example of this is the SSLCertificate param in the enable-tls
  environment file.
- resource_registry: Many environments also need to pass
  resource_registry entries when they are used.  This can be used
  to specify that in the configuration file.

I've written up sample environment configs for a number of the
existing environments as a PoC, and I'm reasonably happy with the
results.  It's unfortunate that any environment using top-level
params has to specify the entire list instead of using 'all' because
it means any new params related to the environment will require
manual addition, but unless we can use parameter groups or something
to codify which params are related I don't see a way around that.

The SSL or cinder-netapp samples are a better example of where this
can be very useful.  They're features whose parameters are entirely
contained in independent templates, so we can simply point the tool
at those templates and grab all the params, except the private ones.
This way, if either of those features ever decides to add more
params, all they have to do is re-generate the sample config with
the tool and the new params will be picked up automatically.

Another significant benefit of the tool is that it normalizes the
format of our sample envs and always includes the param description
in the sample env so users know what they're setting.  That also
means that if a description for a param is updated in the templates
it won't have to be manually copy-pasted into the sample env.

Change-Id: I855f33a61bba5337d844555a7c41b633b3327f7a
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-12-15 17:20:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/f8c706b17325f412d3e3d68ea7f86c132094e9ea', 'message': "Sample environment generator

This is a tool to automate the generation of our sample environment
files.  It takes a yaml file as input, and based on the environments
defined in that file generates a number of sample environment files
from the parameters in the Heat templates.  A tox genconfig target
is added that mirrors how the other OpenStack services generate
their sample config files.

A basic rundown of the settings in the input file (these explanations
are also included in a README file):
- name: the output file will be this name + .yaml
- description: A description of the environment.  Will be included
  as a comment at the top of the sample file.
- files: The Heat templates containing the parameter definitions
  for the environment.
- parameters: This can be either a list of parameters related to
  the environment, which is necessary for templates like
  overcloud.yaml, or the string 'all', which indicates that all
  parameters from $files should be included.
- immutable: Can be used to specify that certain parameters must
  not be changed.  Examples would be the EnableSomething params

  then EnableSomething: True would be an immutable param.
- private: Used to specify that some parameters are only for
  internal communication between the templates and should not be
  included in the sample file (this would only be useful for the
  'all' parameters setting).
- sample_values: Sometimes it is useful to include a sample value
  for a parameter that is not the parameter's actual default.
  An example of this is the SSLCertificate param in the enable-tls
  environment file.
- resource_registry: Many environments also need to pass
  resource_registry entries when they are used.  This can be used
  to specify that in the configuration file.

I've written up sample environment configs for a number of the
existing environments as a PoC, and I'm reasonably happy with the
results.  As composable services proceeds things will probably
improve even more as we can stop pulling params out of overcloud.yaml
and just grab everything from the service-specific files.

The SSL or cinder-netapp samples are a better example of where this
can be very useful.  They're features whose parameters are mostly
contained in independent templates, so we can simply point the tool
at those templates and grab all the params, except the private ones.
This way, if either of those features ever decides to add more
params, all they have to do is re-generate the sample config with
the tool and the new params will be picked up automatically.

Another significant benefit of the tool is that it normalizes the
format of our sample envs and always includes the param description
in the sample env so users know what they're setting.  That also
means that if a description for a param is updated in the templates
it won't have to be manually copy-pasted into the sample env.

Change-Id: I855f33a61bba5337d844555a7c41b633b3327f7a
"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2016-05-03 18:49:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/22298e93a4357a678ad49c15e6237cb07b35909f', 'message': "Sample environment generator

This is a tool to automate the generation of our sample environment
files.  It takes a yaml file as input, and based on the environments
defined in that file generates a number of sample environment files
from the parameters in the Heat templates.  A tox genconfig target
is added that mirrors how the other OpenStack services generate
their sample config files.

A basic rundown of the settings in the input file (these explanations
are also included in a README file):
- name: the output file will be this name + .yaml
- description: A description of the environment.  Will be included
  as a comment at the top of the sample file.
- files: The Heat templates containing the parameter definitions
  for the environment.
- parameters: This can be either a list of parameters related to
  the environment, which is necessary for templates like
  overcloud.yaml, or the string 'all', which indicates that all
  parameters from $files should be included.
- immutable: Can be used to specify that certain parameters must
  not be changed.  Examples would be the EnableSomething params
  in the templates.  If you're writing a sample config for Something
  then EnableSomething: True would be an immutable param.
- private: Used to specify that some parameters are only for
  internal communication between the templates and should not be
  included in the sample file (this would only be useful for the
  'all' parameters setting).
- sample_values: Sometimes it is useful to include a sample value
  for a parameter that is not the parameter's actual default.
  An example of this is the SSLCertificate param in the enable-tls
  environment file.
- resource_registry: Many environments also need to pass
  resource_registry entries when they are used.  This can be used
  to specify that in the configuration file.

I've written up sample environment configs for a number of the
existing environments as a PoC, and I'm reasonably happy with the
results.  As composable services proceeds things will probably
improve even more as we can stop pulling params out of overcloud.yaml
and just grab everything from the service-specific files.

The SSL or cinder-netapp samples are a better example of where this
can be very useful.  They're features whose parameters are mostly
contained in independent templates, so we can simply point the tool
at those templates and grab all the params, except the private ones.
This way, if either of those features ever decides to add more
params, all they have to do is re-generate the sample config with
the tool and the new params will be picked up automatically.

Another significant benefit of the tool is that it normalizes the
format of our sample envs and always includes the param description
in the sample env so users know what they're setting.  That also
means that if a description for a param is updated in the templates
it won't have to be manually copy-pasted into the sample env.

Change-Id: I855f33a61bba5337d844555a7c41b633b3327f7a

commit_message:
Sample environment generator

This is a tool to automate the generation of our sample environment
files.  It takes a yaml file as input, and based on the environments
defined in that file generates a number of sample environment files
from the parameters in the Heat templates.  A tox genconfig target
is added that mirrors how the other OpenStack services generate
their sample config files.

A description of the available options for the input file is
provided in a README file in the sample-env-generator directory.

In this commit only a single sample config is provided as a basic
example of how the tool works, but subsequent commits will add
more generated sample configs.

Change-Id: I855f33a61bba5337d844555a7c41b633b3327f7a
bp: environment-generator

added_lines: # A Heat environment file which can be used to enable the # use of an externally managed Ceph cluster. parameters: # The Ceph client key. Can be created with ceph-authtool --gen-print-key. Currently only used for external Ceph deployments to create the openstack user keyring. # Type: string CephClientKey: '' # The Ceph cluster FSID. Must be a UUID. # Type: string CephClusterFSID: '' # List of externally managed Ceph Mon Host IPs. Only used for external Ceph deployments. # Type: string CephExternalMonHost: '' # Whether to enable or not the Iscsi backend for Cinder # Type: boolean CinderEnableIscsiBackend: False # Whether to enable or not the Rbd backend for Cinder # Type: boolean CinderEnableRbdBackend: True # Whether to deploy Ceph Storage (OSD) on the Controller # Type: boolean ControllerEnableCephStorage: False # The short name of the Glance backend to use. Should be one of swift, rbd or file # Type: string GlanceBackend: rbd # Whether to enable or not the Rbd backend for Nova # Type: boolean NovaEnableRbdBackend: True parameter_defaults: # # Type: string CephClientUserName: openstack # # Type: string CinderRbdPoolName: volumes # # Type: string GlanceRbdPoolName: images # # Type: string NovaRbdPoolName: vms resource_registry: OS::TripleO::CephClusterConfig::SoftwareConfig: ../puppet/extraconfig/ceph/ceph-external-config.yaml

commit_message:
Stop arping when interface gets deleted

It is possible for an interface to be added to a
router, have arping get started for it in a thread,
then immediately remove the interface, causing
arping errors in the l3-agent log.  This concurrent
deletion should be handled more gracefully by
just logging a warning on the first detection and
returning early.

Change-Id: I615b60561b3b7f8c950d5f412fb4cdf7877b98f7
Closes-bug: #1696893
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/00/472500/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Since this is spawned in a thread and executed 1 second # apart, the interface may have been deleted while we were # sleeping. Downgrade message to a warning and return early. exists = device_exists(iface_name, namespace=ns_name) if not (log_exception or exists): if not exists: LOG.warning("Interface %s might have been deleted " "concurrently", iface_name) return

commit_message:
Add WSGI support script for murano API

This patch add scripts for running API serces via WSGI.
The follow-up patch will add the devstack install support.

Change-Id: I3b836041559004a629f2cb2a506e53bf04fbdf23
Partially-Implements: blueprint murano-api-wsgi

commit_message:
[log]: db models and migration rules

This patch includes db models and migration rules for initial
logging object. The implementation bases on logging api for
security group spec[1]

[1] https://goo.gl/t3NUlr

Partially-implements: blueprint security-group-logging
Related-Bug: #1468366

Change-Id: I3f91b3927c33021facc9eb9238555c0e06a918c0

subject: Added Nova Compute CPU metrics to gnocchi_resources.yaml
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-26 19:32:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/c6ae8ddae156d1ab04dee06a0806d3a94442a894', 'message': 'Added Nova Compute CPU metrics to gnocchi_resources.yaml

By default, there is no supporting configuration in Ceilometer
to handle CPU monitors provided by the Nova compute_monitors
driver (cpu.virt_driver in this case).

Added metric defitions provided by cpu.virt_driver to the host
resource type in ceilometer/dispatcher/data/gnocchi_resources.yaml
to enable these to be passed by the dispatcher to Gnocchi.

Change-Id: I7698ba3168f79d05943042971039aea9a4c4e1a9
Closes-Bug: #1693846

commit_message:
Added Nova Compute CPU metrics to gnocchi_resources.yaml

By default, there is no supporting configuration in Ceilometer
to handle CPU monitors provided by the Nova compute_monitors
driver (cpu.virt_driver in this case).

Added metric defitions provided by cpu.virt_driver to
ceilometer/dispatcher/data/gnocchi_resources.yaml under a new
resource type, nova_compute. This enables these metrics to be
passed by the dispatcher to Gnocchi.

Added create_resource_type operation to gnocchi_client
upgrade_resource_types operations.  This way the resources_initial
dict can stay static, but new resource types can be added as
needed by the upgrade resource types function.

Change-Id: I7698ba3168f79d05943042971039aea9a4c4e1a9
Closes-Bug: #1693846
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/22/468522/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Correct config path in functional test

We provide two ways to load castellan-functional.conf, but specify a wrong path
in the repo, this patch fixes that. Also clarify the description in doc.

Change-Id: Id05b11e70a0ed46fcdd922a5f22f86df87b930ae

Fix error in credential_factory

project_domain_id and project_domain_name are not correctly referenced
in credential_factory. This patch fixes that.

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-08 07:51:27.000000000', 'files': ['lib/tls'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/379def9320ec8d139fc95921ec9ea4700c7434b1', 'message': 'fix USE_SSL=True installation of devstack

bug happens because certificate is created with CN=localhost
but endpoints are created with IP of host (192.168.X.Y for example).
and due to this difference error is occured.
I propose to use SERVICE_HOST variable (that is used to create endpoint)
for certificate`s creation (for CN).

Change-Id: I938d73fc9919efe3188c09f6c120c08ed68d9d04
Closes-Bug: #1514044
'}]
commit_message:
fix USE_SSL=True installation of devstack

bug happens because certificate is created with CN=localhost
but endpoints are created with IP of host (192.168.X.Y for example).
and due to this difference error is occured.
I propose to use SERVICE_HOST variable (that is used to create endpoint)
for certificate`s creation (for CN).

Change-Id: I938d73fc9919efe3188c09f6c120c08ed68d9d04
Closes-Bug: #1514044
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/12/242812/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add list of DNS servers for the undercloud

Pass multiple DNS servers to the undercloud set up.
This serves as a backup if the primary DNS server is down.
The overcloud was set up with multiple DNS servers already.

Change-Id: If94b4c770c26adf7df7b8f9dd7e8c67997dfec6a

subject: Make mount_check option usable in containerized environments
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-19 10:17:28.000000000', 'files': ['swift/common/utils.py', 'test/unit/common/test_utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/5eeaa95440aa01c6be2c58c7959e70dbed7bfb69', 'message': 'Make mount_check option usable in containerized environments

The ismount_raw method does not work inside containers if disks are
mounted on the hostsystem and only mountpoints are exposed inside the
containers. In this case the inode and device checks fail, making this
option unusable.

Mounting devices into the containers would solve this. However, this
would require that all processes that require access to a device are
running inside the same container, which counteracts the container
concept.

This patch adds the possiblity to place stubfiles named ".ismount" into
the root directory of any device, and Swift assumes a given device to be
mounted if that file exists. This should be transparent to existing
clusters.

Change-Id: I9d9fc0a4447a8c5dd39ca60b274c119af6b4c28f
'}]
commit_message:
Make mount_check option usable in containerized environments

The ismount_raw method does not work inside containers if disks are
mounted on the hostsystem and only mountpoints are exposed inside the
containers. In this case the inode and device checks fail, making this
option unusable.

Mounting devices into the containers would solve this. However, this
would require that all processes that require access to a device are
running inside the same container, which counteracts the container
concept.

This patch adds the possiblity to place stubfiles named ".ismount" into
the root directory of any device, and Swift assumes a given device to be
mounted if that file exists. This should be transparent to existing
clusters.

Change-Id: I9d9fc0a4447a8c5dd39ca60b274c119af6b4c28f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/55/466255/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_ismount_successes_stubfile(self): tmpdir = mkdtemp() fname = os.path.join(tmpdir, ".ismount") try: with open(fname, "w") as stubfile: stubfile.write("") self.assertTrue(utils.ismount(tmpdir)) finally: shutil.rmtree(tmpdir)

commit_message:
Remove log translations

Log messages are no longer being translated. This removes all use of
the _LE, _LI, and _LW translation markers to simplify logging and to
avoid confusion with new contributions.

See:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-i18n/2016-November/002574.html
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/113365.html

Co-Authored-By: wanghao<sxmatch1986@gmail.com>

Closes-Bug: #1675247

Change-Id: I32dcbafd0f001ca4e1bf847735102e4bb22d37a5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/86/448086/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # Translators for log levels. # # The abbreviated names are meant to reflect the usual use of a short # name like '_'. The "L" is for "log" and the other letter comes from # the level. _LI = _translators.log_info _LW = _translators.log_warning _LE = _translators.log_error _LC = _translators.log_critical

commit_message:
De-client-ify Project Update

Change-Id: I2c9c6ebe594268b1be78af7b1e25f110605a076d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/29/473629/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @_utils.valid_kwargs('description') def update_project(self, name_or_id, enabled=True, domain_id=None, **kwargs): kwargs.update({'enabled': enabled}) # NOTE(samueldmq): Current code only allow updates of description # or enabled fields. # FIXME(samueldmq): enable=True is the default, meaning it will # enable a disabled project if you simply update other fields if self.cloud_config.get_api_version('identity') == '3': project = self._identity_client.patch( '/projects/' + proj['id'], data=kwargs) else: project = self._identity_client.post( '/tenants/' + proj['id'], data=kwargs) project = self._normalize_project(project)
deleted_lines: def update_project(self, name_or_id, description=None, enabled=True, domain_id=None): params = {} if self.cloud_config.get_api_version('identity') == '3': params['project'] = proj['id'] else: params['tenant_id'] = proj['id'] project = self._normalize_project( self.manager.submit_task(_tasks.ProjectUpdate( description=description, enabled=enabled, **params)))

commit_message:
De-client-ify Project Create

Change-Id: I4003cda72ac6f4bfc083722983159409673d3098
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/09/473609/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _get_domain_id_param_dict(self, domain_id): """Get a useable domain.""" # Keystone v3 requires domains for user and project creation. v2 does # not. However, keystone v2 does not allow user creation by non-admin # users, so we can throw an error to the user that does not need to # mention api versions if self.cloud_config.get_api_version('identity') == '3': if not domain_id: raise OpenStackCloudException( "User or project creation requires an explicit" " domain_id argument.") else: return {'domain_id': domain_id} else: return {} # TODO(samueldmq): Get rid of this method once create_user is migrated to # REST and, consequently, _get_domain_id_param_dict is used instead project_ref = self._get_domain_id_param_dict(domain_id) project_ref.update({'name': name, 'description': description, 'enabled': enabled}) if self.cloud_config.get_api_version('identity') == '3': project = self._identity_client.post('/projects', json=project_ref) else: project = self._identity_client.post('/tenants', json=project_ref) project = self._normalize_project(project)
deleted_lines: params = self._get_domain_param_dict(domain_id) if self.cloud_config.get_api_version('identity') == '3': params['name'] = name else: params['tenant_name'] = name project = self._normalize_project( self.manager.submit_task(_tasks.ProjectCreate( project_name=name, description=description, enabled=enabled, **params)))

subject: Add version column
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-19 10:43:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/7e685f368925c90708876e7da212458529173154', 'message': 'Add version column

This extends versioned objects and uses the obj_make_compatible
methods to also convert between versioned data stored in the database.

Version column is introduced to make sure reading the DB object
versions happens transparently for the developer and throws an
exception in case of a version compatibility error.

The version column is null at first and will be filled with the
appropriate versions by a data migration script in a following patch.

Change-Id: I34629a5cbab7ff3f246ea19c0cb766badc7061db
Partial-Bug: #1526283
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-12-19 12:22:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/a0bc4c340cbb826bf023b2ac64cf71dbb0499146', 'message': 'Add version column

This extends versioned objects and uses the obj_make_compatible
methods to also convert between versioned data stored in the database.

Version column is introduced to make sure reading the DB object
versions happens transparently for the developer and throws an
exception in case of a version compatibility error.

commit_message:
Add version column

This extends versioned objects and uses the object's
convert_to_version() to perform conversions between different
versions of the object. This conversion is only done at the
"boundaries" of the api and conductor services. That is, when
reading/writing to the database and when serializing/deserializing
(for RPC). Internally, the services deal with the latest versions
of the objects.

Version column is introduced to make sure reading the DB object
versions happens transparently for the developer. An exception
is raised in case of a version compatibility error.

The version column is null at first and will be filled with the
appropriate versions by a data migration script in a following patch.

Change-Id: I34629a5cbab7ff3f246ea19c0cb766badc7061db
Partial-Bug: #1526283
Co-Authored-By: Ruby Loo <ruby.loo@intel.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/97/412397/30 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_versionedobjects import exception _original_version = None @property def _unpinned(self): """Individual object instances can be unpinned If object is unpinned, obj_make_compatible methods are not called, even if pin_release_version configuration is set. """ return self._original_version == self.VERSION def obj_get_changes(self): """Returns a dict of changed fields and their new values.""" changes = super(IronicObject, self).obj_get_changes() version_manifest = self._get_version_manifest() target_version = self._get_target_version() if target_version != self.VERSION: # convert changes to older format self.obj_make_compatible_from_manifest( changes, target_version, version_manifest) if self._original_version != target_version: # version change changes['version'] = target_version return changes def obj_reset_changes(self): self._original_version = self._get_target_version() # reset version return super(IronicObject, self).obj_reset_changes() objname = obj.obj_name() objver = db_object['version'] obj._original_version = objver if objver is None: # backfill versions for newton release objver = versions.RELEASE_MAPPING['newton']['objects'][objname] if not versionutils.is_compatible(objver, obj.VERSION): raise exception.IncompatibleObjectVersion( objname=objname, objver=objver, supported=obj.VERSION) @staticmethod def _get_version_manifest(): pin = CONF.pin_release_version if pin: return versions.RELEASE_MAPPING[pin]['objects'] def _get_target_version(self): if self._unpinned: return self.VERSION version_manifest = self._get_version_manifest() if version_manifest: return version_manifest[self.obj_name()] return self.VERSION

commit_message:
Redis 'repl-backlog-size' conf parameter using wrong MIN value

Redis configuration validation for the 'repl-backlog-size' parameter
uses a wrong MIN value of '0'.When set to less than 16384 value,
I can see that the value in redis.conf[1], but through the
'config get *' see are 16384[2]. Because the minimum default value
in redis is 16384[3]. So I want to modify Min value to 16384.

[1]: repl-backlog-size 0
[2]: 59) "repl-backlog-size"
     60) "16384"
[3]:https://github.com/antirez/redis/blob/58f79e2ff48bb20e48d5eb60ff6a87c9afae5fe9/src/server.h#L110

Closes-Bug: #1697596
Change-Id: I81cb1c02943edf0af3d7bf67ff2f083a4c07d518

commit_message:
Fix urljoin for neutron endpoint

We just add a '/v2.0' to the catalog endpoint for neutron. However, if
the catalog endpoint does not end in a /, this can turn
https://domain.tld/neutron into https://domain.tld/v2.0 instead of
https://domain.tld/neutron/v2.0 as intended.

Change-Id: If16dc64dd9a4c9e525d042190632d0f4f0a4fb63
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/62/474162/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: catalog_endpoint = client.get_endpoint() if not catalog_endpoint.endswith('/'): catalog_endpoint += '/' catalog_endpoint, 'v2.0')

commit_message:
fix an infinite loop in the topo traversal algorithm

When skipping null-merges, do not go back to the first parent node if we
have already processed it.

Fix a similar potential issue when handling parent nodes during regular
processing.

Change-Id: I10e531cdf3b203ca2e9249d89a37b61f79091311
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Add multiprocessing worker to reconstructor

This is a sketch of the basic idea for first step, it seems to pass
some tests...

Change-Id: Ia9de630cd161137aa83b278f4d23bb71888d7112
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/56/443356/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Return those suffixes which should be synced. :param local_suff: the local suffix hashes (from _get_hashes) :param local_index: the local fragment index for the job :param remote_suff: the remote suffix hashes (from remote REPLICATE request) :param remote_index: the remote fragment index for the job :returns: a list of strings, the suffix dirs to sync """ suffixes = [] for suffix, sub_dict_local in local_suff.items(): sub_dict_remote = remote_suff.get(suffix, {}) if (sub_dict_local.get(None) != sub_dict_remote.get(None) or sub_dict_local.get(local_index) != sub_dict_remote.get(remote_index)): suffixes.append(suffix) return suffixes class ObjectReconstructorWorker(object): ec_policies = (policy for policy in POLICIES if policy.policy_type == EC_POLICY) for policy in ec_policies: policy.load_ring(self.swift_dir) self.headers = { 'user-agent': 'obj-reconstructor %s' % os.getpid()} self.http_timeout = int(conf.get('http_timeout', 60)) # these options are here just for ssync self.network_chunk_size = int(conf.get('network_chunk_size', 65536)) self.disk_chunk_size = int(conf.get('disk_chunk_size', 65536)) def delete_reverted_objs(self, job, objects, frag_index): For EC we can potentially revert only some of a partition so we'll delete reverted objects here. Note that we delete the fragment index of the file we sent to the remote node. :param job: the job being processed :param objects: a dict of objects to be deleted, each entry maps hash=>timestamp :param frag_index: (int) the fragment index of data files to be deleted df_mgr = self._df_router[job['policy']] for object_hash, timestamps in objects.items(): try: df = df_mgr.get_diskfile_from_hash( job['local_dev']['device'], job['partition'], object_hash, job['policy'], frag_index=frag_index) df.purge(timestamps['ts_data'], frag_index) except DiskFileError: self.logger.exception( 'Unable to purge DiskFile (%r %r %r)', object_hash, timestamps['ts_data'], frag_index) def rehash_remote(self, node, job, suffixes): headers = self.headers.copy() headers['X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index'] = int(job['policy']) try: with Timeout(self.http_timeout): conn = http_connect( node['replication_ip'], node['replication_port'], node['device'], job['partition'], 'REPLICATE', '/' + '-'.join(sorted(suffixes)), headers=headers) conn.getresponse().read() except (Exception, Timeout): self.logger.exception( _("Trying to sync suffixes with %s") % _full_path( node, job['partition'], '', job['policy'])) def _revert(self, job, begin): Process a REVERT job. """ self.logger.increment( 'partition.delete.count.%s' % (job['local_dev']['device'],)) handoff_remaining = False syncd_with = 0 reverted_objs = {} for node in job['sync_to']: success, in_sync_objs = ssync_sender( self, node, job, job['suffixes'])() self.rehash_remote(node, job, job['suffixes']) if success: syncd_with += 1 reverted_objs.update(in_sync_objs) if syncd_with >= len(job['sync_to']): self.delete_reverted_objs( job, reverted_objs, job['frag_index']) else: handoff_remaining = True self.logger.timing_since('partition.delete.timing', begin) return {'handoff_remaining': handoff_remaining} def _get_hashes(self, policy, path, recalculate=None, do_listdir=False): df_mgr = self._df_router[policy] hashed, suffix_hashes = tpool_reraise( df_mgr._get_hashes, path, recalculate=recalculate, do_listdir=do_listdir) self.logger.update_stats('suffix.hashes', hashed) return suffix_hashes def _get_suffixes_to_sync(self, job, node): """ For SYNC jobs we need to make a remote REPLICATE request to get the remote node's current suffix's hashes and then compare to our local suffix's hashes to decide which suffixes (if any) are out of sync. :param: the job dict, with the keys defined in ``_get_part_jobs`` :param node: the remote node dict :returns: a (possibly empty) list of strings, the suffixes to be synced with the remote node. """ # get hashes from the remote node headers = self.headers.copy() headers['X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index'] = int(job['policy']) remote_suffixes = None try: with Timeout(self.http_timeout): resp = http_connect( node['replication_ip'], node['replication_port'], node['device'], job['partition'], 'REPLICATE', '', headers=headers).getresponse() if resp.status == HTTP_INSUFFICIENT_STORAGE: self.logger.error( _('%s responded as unmounted'), _full_path(node, job['partition'], '', job['policy'])) elif resp.status != HTTP_OK: full_path = _full_path(node, job['partition'], '', job['policy']) self.logger.error( _("Invalid response %(resp)s from %(full_path)s"), {'resp': resp.status, 'full_path': full_path}) else: remote_suffixes = pickle.loads(resp.read()) except (Exception, Timeout): # all exceptions are logged here so that our caller can # safely catch our exception and continue to the next node # without logging self.logger.exception('Unable to get remote suffix hashes ' 'from %r' % _full_path( node, job['partition'], '', job['policy'])) if remote_suffixes is None: raise SuffixSyncError('Unable to get remote suffix hashes') suffixes = get_suffix_delta(job['hashes'], job['frag_index'], remote_suffixes, node['index']) # now recalculate local hashes for suffixes that don't # match so we're comparing the latest local_suff = self._get_hashes(job['policy'], job['path'], recalculate=suffixes) suffixes = get_suffix_delta(local_suff, job['frag_index'], remote_suffixes, node['index']) return suffixes full_path = _full_path(node, part, path, policy) def _reconstruct(self, policy, fragment_payload, frag_index): return policy.pyeclib_driver.reconstruct(fragment_payload, [frag_index])[0] def make_rebuilt_fragment_iter(self, responses, path, policy, frag_index): """ Turn a set of connections from backend object servers into a generator that yields up the rebuilt fragment archive for frag_index. """ def _get_one_fragment(resp): buff = '' remaining_bytes = policy.fragment_size while remaining_bytes: chunk = resp.read(remaining_bytes) if not chunk: break remaining_bytes -= len(chunk) buff += chunk return buff def fragment_payload_iter(): # We need a fragment from each connections, so best to # use a GreenPile to keep them ordered and in sync pile = GreenPile(len(responses)) while True: for resp in responses: pile.spawn(_get_one_fragment, resp) try: with Timeout(self.node_timeout): fragment_payload = [fragment for fragment in pile] except (Exception, Timeout): self.logger.exception( _("Error trying to rebuild %(path)s " "policy#%(policy)d frag#%(frag_index)s"), {'path': path, 'policy': policy, 'frag_index': frag_index, }) break if not all(fragment_payload): break rebuilt_fragment = self._reconstruct( policy, fragment_payload, frag_index) yield rebuilt_fragment return fragment_payload_iter() unique_index, fi_to_rebuild, _full_path( _full_path(node, job['partition'], datafile_metadata['name'], job['policy'])) _full_path(node, job['partition'], datafile_metadata['name'], job['policy']), _full_path(node, job['partition'], datafile_metadata['name'], job['policy']))) def _sync(self, job, begin): Process a SYNC job. self.logger.increment( 'partition.update.count.%s' % (job['local_dev']['device'],)) # after our left and right partners, if there's some sort of # failure we'll continue onto the remaining primary nodes and # make sure they're in sync - or potentially rebuild missing # fragments we find dest_nodes = itertools.chain( job['sync_to'], # I think we could order these based on our index to better # protect against a broken chain [ n for n in job['policy'].object_ring.get_part_nodes(job['partition']) if n['id'] != job['local_dev']['id'] and n['id'] not in (m['id'] for m in job['sync_to']) ], ) syncd_with = 0 result = { 'suffix_count': 0, 'suffix_sync': 0, } for node in dest_nodes: if syncd_with >= len(job['sync_to']): # success! break try: suffixes = self._get_suffixes_to_sync(job, node) except SuffixSyncError: continue if not suffixes: syncd_with += 1 continue # update stats for this attempt self.logger.update_stats('suffix.count', len(suffixes)) result['suffix_count'] += len(suffixes) # ssync any out-of-sync suffixes with the remote node job['sync_diskfile_builder'] = self.reconstruct_fa success, _ = ssync_sender( self, node, job, suffixes)() # let remote end know to rehash it's suffixes self.rehash_remote(node, job, suffixes) if success: # update stats for this success self.logger.update_stats('suffix.syncs', len(suffixes)) result['suffix_sync'] += len(suffixes) syncd_with += 1 self.logger.timing_since('partition.update.timing', begin) return result def process_job(self, job): """ Sync the local partition with the remote node(s) according to the parameters of the job. For primary nodes, the SYNC job type will define both left and right hand sync_to nodes to ssync with as defined by this primary nodes index in the node list based on the fragment index found in the partition. For non-primary nodes (either handoff revert, or rebalance) the REVERT job will define a single node in sync_to which is the proper/new home for the fragment index. N.B. ring rebalancing can be time consuming and handoff nodes' fragment indexes do not have a stable order, it's possible to have more than one REVERT job for a partition, and in some rare failure conditions there may even also be a SYNC job for the same partition - but each one will be processed separately because each job will define a separate list of node(s) to 'sync_to'. :param: the job dict, with the keys defined in ``_get_job_info`` """ begin = time.time() if job['job_type'] == REVERT: result = self._revert(job, begin) else: result = self._sync(job, begin) result.update({ 'job': job, 'partition_time': time.time() - begin, }) return result def process_jobs(conf, job_q, result_q): worker = ObjectReconstructorWorker(conf) run_pool = GreenPool(size=worker.concurrency) while True: job = job_q.get() if job is None: break policy = POLICIES.get_by_index(job['policy_index']) if not policy: worker.logger.error(_("No policy with index %s") % job['policy_index']) continue job['policy'] = policy def inner(job): result = worker.process_job(job) result['job']['policy_index'] = int(result['job'].pop('policy')) result['job'].pop('sync_diskfile_builder', None) result_q.put(result) run_pool.spawn(inner, job) run_pool.waitall() class ObjectReconstructor(Daemon): """ Reconstruct objects using erasure code. And also rebalance EC Fragment Archive objects off handoff nodes. Encapsulates most logic and data needed by the object reconstruction process. Each call to .reconstruct() performs one pass. It's up to the caller to do this in a loop. """ def __init__(self, conf, logger=None): """ :param conf: configuration object obtained from ConfigParser :param logger: logging object """ self.conf = conf self.logger = logger or get_logger( conf, log_route='object-reconstructor') self.devices_dir = conf.get('devices', '/srv/node') self.mount_check = config_true_value(conf.get('mount_check', 'true')) self.swift_dir = conf.get('swift_dir', '/etc/swift') self.bind_ip = conf.get('bind_ip', '0.0.0.0') self.servers_per_port = int(conf.get('servers_per_port', '0') or 0) self.port = None if self.servers_per_port else \ int(conf.get('bind_port', 6200)) self.concurrency = int(conf.get('concurrency', 1)) self.workers = int(conf.get('workers', 1)) self.stats_interval = int(conf.get('stats_interval', '300')) self.ring_check_interval = int(conf.get('ring_check_interval', 15)) self.next_check = time.time() + self.ring_check_interval self.partition_times = [] self.interval = int(conf.get('interval') or conf.get('run_pause') or 30) self.lockup_timeout = int(conf.get('lockup_timeout', 1800)) self.recon_cache_path = conf.get('recon_cache_path', '/var/cache/swift') self.rcache = os.path.join(self.recon_cache_path, "object.recon") # defaults subject to change after beta if 'handoffs_first' in conf: self.logger.warning( 'The handoffs_first option is deprecated in favor ' 'of handoffs_only. This option may be ignored in a ' 'future release.') # honor handoffs_first for backwards compatibility default_handoffs_only = config_true_value(conf['handoffs_first']) else: default_handoffs_only = False self.handoffs_only = config_true_value( conf.get('handoffs_only', default_handoffs_only)) if self.handoffs_only: self.logger.warning( 'Handoff only mode is not intended for normal ' 'operation, use handoffs_only with care.') elif default_handoffs_only: self.logger.warning('Ignored handoffs_first option in favor ' 'of handoffs_only.') self._df_router = DiskFileRouter(conf, self.logger) def load_object_ring(self, policy): """ Make sure the policy's rings are loaded. :param policy: the StoragePolicy instance :returns: appropriate ring object """ policy.load_ring(self.swift_dir) return policy.object_ring def check_ring(self, object_ring): """ Check to see if the ring has been updated :param object_ring: the ring to check :returns: boolean indicating whether or not the ring has changed """ if time.time() > self.next_check: self.next_check = time.time() + self.ring_check_interval if object_ring.has_changed(): return False return True def heartbeat(self, result_q): last_stats_line = time.time() while True: try: result = result_q.get(timeout=self.stats_interval) except Empty: pass else: if result is None: return self.partition_times.append(result['partition_time']) self.reconstruction_count += 1 if result.get('handoff_remaining', False): self.handoffs_remaining += 1 self.suffix_count += result.get('suffix_count', 0) self.suffix_sync += result.get('suffix_sync', 0) now = time.time() if now >= last_stats_line + self.stats_interval: self.stats_line() last_stats_line = now 'policy_index': int(policy), def _get_hashes(self, policy, path, recalculate=None, do_listdir=False): df_mgr = self._df_router[policy] hashed, suffix_hashes = df_mgr._get_hashes( path, recalculate=recalculate, do_listdir=do_listdir) self.logger.update_stats('suffix.hashes', hashed) return suffix_hashes job_q = Queue(20) result_q = Queue(20) workers = [] for i in range(self.workers): worker = Process(target=process_jobs, args=( self.conf, job_q, result_q)) worker.start() workers.append(worker) stats = spawn(self.heartbeat, result_q) # sleep() # Give spawns a cycle job_q.put(job) for worker in workers: job_q.put(None) for worker in workers: worker.join() result_q.put(None) stats.wait()

For primary nodes, the SYNC job type will define both left and right hand sync_to nodes to ssync with as defined by this primary nodes index in the node list based on the fragment index found in the partition. For non-primary nodes (either handoff revert, or rebalance) the REVERT job will define a single node in sync_to which is the proper/new home for the fragment index. N.B. ring rebalancing can be time consuming and handoff nodes' fragment indexes do not have a stable order, it's possible to have more than one REVERT job for a partition, and in some rare failure conditions there may even also be a SYNC job for the same partition - but each one will be processed separately because each job will define a separate list of node(s) to 'sync_to'. :param: the job dict, with the keys defined in ``_get_job_info`` """ self.headers['X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index'] = int(job['policy']) begin = time.time() if job['job_type'] == REVERT: self._revert(job, begin) else: self._sync(job, begin) self.partition_times.append(time.time() - begin) self.reconstruction_count += 1 def _sync(self, job, begin): """ Process a SYNC job. """ self.logger.increment( 'partition.update.count.%s' % (job['local_dev']['device'],)) # after our left and right partners, if there's some sort of # failure we'll continue onto the remaining primary nodes and # make sure they're in sync - or potentially rebuild missing # fragments we find dest_nodes = itertools.chain( job['sync_to'], # I think we could order these based on our index to better # protect against a broken chain [ n for n in job['policy'].object_ring.get_part_nodes(job['partition']) if n['id'] != job['local_dev']['id'] and n['id'] not in (m['id'] for m in job['sync_to']) ], ) syncd_with = 0 for node in dest_nodes: if syncd_with >= len(job['sync_to']): # success! break try: suffixes = self._get_suffixes_to_sync(job, node) except SuffixSyncError: continue if not suffixes: syncd_with += 1 continue # ssync any out-of-sync suffixes with the remote node success, _ = ssync_sender( self, node, job, suffixes)() # let remote end know to rehash it's suffixes self.rehash_remote(node, job, suffixes) # update stats for this attempt self.suffix_sync += len(suffixes) self.logger.update_stats('suffix.syncs', len(suffixes)) if success: syncd_with += 1 self.logger.timing_since('partition.update.timing', begin) def _revert(self, job, begin): """ Process a REVERT job. """ self.logger.increment( 'partition.delete.count.%s' % (job['local_dev']['device'],)) syncd_with = 0 reverted_objs = {} for node in job['sync_to']: success, in_sync_objs = ssync_sender( self, node, job, job['suffixes'])() self.rehash_remote(node, job, job['suffixes']) if success: syncd_with += 1 reverted_objs.update(in_sync_objs) if syncd_with >= len(job['sync_to']): self.delete_reverted_objs( job, reverted_objs, job['frag_index']) else: self.handoffs_remaining += 1 self.logger.timing_since('partition.delete.timing', begin) 'policy': policy, # ssync callback to rebuild missing fragment_archives sync_job['sync_diskfile_builder'] = self.reconstruct_fa stats = spawn(self.heartbeat) sleep() # Give spawns a cycle self.run_pool.spawn(self.process_job, job) with Timeout(self.lockup_timeout): self.run_pool.waitall() stats.kill()

commit_message:
Fix warning messages in check_remote_connectivity

A RemoteClient object has no "host" attribute, so currently we cause an
exception when trying to handle an error in the
check_remote_connectivity function. Add a new message parameter to be
used in the warning that is logged.

Change-Id: I362cafa08a4a9f8da008e1c905c6b989ddc2bd5e

commit_message:
Disable PrivateDevices for Galera on CentOS 7

This patch adds the `galera_disable_privatedevices` variable that
allows deployers to disable PrivateDevices in the systemd unit file
shipped with MariaDB 10.1+ on CentOS 7 systems.

This is a workaround to fix the systemd/LXC issues with bind
mounting an already bind mounted `/dev/ptmx` inside the LXC
container.

See Launchpad bug, lxc/lxc#1623, or systemd/systemd#6121 for more
details.

Co-Authored-By: Major Hayden <major@mhtx.net>
Closes-bug: 1697531
Change-Id: I8a74113bd16a768a4754fb1f6ee04caf1ac82920
(cherry picked from commit f46e1525069299297eec1df704607848dd7a7b2f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-galera_server refs/changes/51/474251/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # MariaDB 10.1+ ships with 'PrivateDevices=True' in the systemd unit file. This # provides some additional security, but it causes problems with creating # mount namespaces on CentOS 7 with systemd 219. While the security # enhancements are helpful on bare metal hosts with multiple services running, # they are not as helpful when MariaDB is running in a container with its own # isolated namespaces. # # Related bugs: # https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1697531 # https://github.com/lxc/lxc/issues/1623 # https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/6121 # # Setting the following variable to 'yes' will disable the PrivateDevices # setting in the systemd unit file for MariaDB on CentOS 7 hosts. galera_disable_privatedevices: no

commit_message:
Shift 20 nodes to nl01.o.o

As we are starting to run more jobs on zuulv3.o.o / nl01.o.o increase
the nodes in our pool to 30. This should should provide plenty of
nodes to grown into.

Change-Id: I248dacd9c789de976eea6f9d96fb706ea30cecb5
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Retry ebtables lock acquisition failures

It seems after the merge of
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/ebtables/+bug/1645324
that ebtables can fail to acquire a lock and bail with an error
255. This adds some retry logic to retry it up to 10 times to
work around this issue.

Closes-Bug: #1697833
Change-Id: Ic9dcf4b236a93e8811413c6ce2c4b82602544c6d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/63/474063/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_utils import excutils import sixfrom neutron.agent.linux import utilsdef _retry_lockfailure(f): @six.wraps(f) def protected(*args, **kwargs): for i in range(10): try: return f(*args, **kwargs) except utils.ProcessExecutionError as e: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception() as ectxt: if e.returncode == 255 and i < 9: ectxt.reraise = False LOG.exception("Retrying after ebtables error.") @_retry_lockfailure

commit_message:
DVR: properly track SNAT traffic

When running DVR, it's possible for traffic to get confused and sent
through SNAT thanks to the way conntrack tracks "new" connections.  This
patch sets "nf_connctrack_tcp_loose" inside the SNAT namespace to more
intelligently handle SNAT traffic (and ignore what should be FIP
traffic) - basically, don't track a connection where we didn't
see the initial SYN.

https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/networking/nf_conntrack-sysctl.txt

Change-Id: Ia5b8bd3794d22808ee1718d429f0bbdbe61e94ec
Closes-Bug: 1620824
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/97/366297/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def create(self): """Create network namespace for SNAT traffic""" LOG.debug("DVR: add snat namespace: %s", self.name) ip_wrapper_root = ip_lib.IPWrapper() ip_wrapper = ip_wrapper.ensure_namespace(self.name) # Set nf_conntrack_tcp_loose to 0 to ensure mid-stream # TCP conversations aren't taken over by SNAT ip_wrapper.netns.execute(['sysctl', '-w', 'net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_tcp_loose=0'], log_fail_as_error=False, run_as_root=True)

commit_message:
fix overaggressive 403->404 conversion

When a user is not authorized to see a given resource, we need to
convert HTTP 403s into HTTP 404s to avoid giving away information
that the resource exists. However, the previous code was being
overaggressive and doing this conversion even in some cases where
the user is allowed to see the resource and really needs to know
that what they were trying to do is forbidden, not be told that the
resource doesn't exist. This fixes that logic to only do the 403
to 404 conversion when truly appropriate.

Change-Id: I7a5b0a9e89c8a71490dd74497794a52489f46cd2
Closes-Bug: 1682621

subject: Explicitly enable Horizon in Horizon dsvm job
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-14 16:40:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/1777789fddec2aec9e80e87abcc84caab226b4bf', 'message': "Explicitly enable Horizon in Horizon dsvm job

We want to disable Horizon by default in jobs that don't actually use or
test Horizon. This will save job runtime because it means installing
fewer packages (which takes time) and happier OSC because fewer packages
impacting pkg_resources entrypoint handling.

commit_message:
Explicitly enable Horizon in Horizon dsvm job

We want to disable Horizon by default in jobs that don't actually use or
test Horizon. This will save job runtime because it means installing
fewer packages (which takes time) and happier OSC because fewer packages
impacting pkg_resources entrypoint handling.

Change-Id: Ib3fdab05bfa5f91678051db5643a976174f4797e

subject: Fix race condition regression
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-14 14:31:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/9792f50a3b7f81a3a2a915d5465ce0f338fdfe73', 'message': 'Fix race condition regression

The building of the group "repo_masters" relies on going through
the inventory, but we never check if the hosts are added in a
particular order. While it should follow the ansible inventory
order (that's the play order by default), the inclusion of the
host to a group could happen at any time, because the play runs
all the hosts in parallel.

If we ensure the hosts are run serially, the addition of the
hosts to the architecture dependant repo_ groups will always

and use it as "repo_master".

commit_message:
Fix race condition regression

The building of the group "repo_masters" relies on going through
the inventory, but we never check if the hosts are added in a
particular order. While it should follow the ansible inventory
order (that's the play order by default), the inclusion of the
host to a group could happen at any time, because the play runs
all the hosts in parallel.

If we ensure the hosts are run serially, the addition of the
hosts to the architecture dependant repo_ groups will always
be done in the right order.

We can then use these groups to find which host is the first one,
and use it as "repo_master".

Closes-Bug: #1697778

Change-Id: I51803dab20e85bd6c100821ce5c1c1ad3226ba29
(cherry picked from commit 28b646eb27c46181a72a8b2133ff9ca60c1d7507)

This ensures that # the repo build happens per architecture and per distribution, covering the needs # of each of these combinations when deploying. - name: Prepare group of master repo servers hosts: localhost tasks: add_host: - "item in groups['repo_servers_' + ansible_distribution_version + '_' + ansible_architecture][0]"
